Nickel/cobalt-layered double hydroxides (NiCo-LDH) have been attracted increasing interest in the applications of anode materials for lithium ion battery (LIB), but the low cycle stability and rate performance are still limited its practice applications. To achieve high performance LIB, the surface-confined strategy has been applied to design and fabricate a new anode material of NiCo-LDH nanosheet anchored on the surface of Ti3C2 MXene (NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2). The ultra-thin, bended and wrinkled α-phase crystal with an interlayer spacing of 8.1 Å can arrange on the conductive substrates Ti3C2 MXene directly, resulting in high electrolyte diffusion ability and low internal resistance. Furthermore, chemical bond interactions between the highly conductive Ti3C2 MXene and NiCo-LDH nanosheets can greatly increase the ion and electron transport and reduce the volume expansion of NiCo-LDH during Li ion intercalation. As expected, the discharge capacity of 562 mAh g−1 at 5.0 A g−1 for 800 cycles without degradation can be achieved, rate capability and cycle performance are better than that of NiCo-LDH (~100 mAh g−1). Furthermore, the density function theory (DFT) calculations were performed to demonstrate that NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 system can be used as a highly desirable and promising anode material for lithium ion battery. Graphical abstract NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 MXene hybrid materials were synthesized by electrostatic attraction strategy. This structure effectively promotes ion diffusion, alleviates the volume expansion for lithium ion battery anode with high-rate capability and long cycle life. Image, graphical abstract Keywords MXene Ti3C2 NiCo-LDH Lithium ion battery First-principles calculation 1 Introduction The layered double hydroxide (LDH) is an inorganic layered material that has been known for over 150 years [1]. The general formula of LDH should be represented as M2+ 1- x M3+ x (OH)2An− x / n ·mH2O [2]. The anion exchange and the structure remains unchanged while changing its own metal cations properties [3], could make LDHs wide applications in the fields of catalysis [4], biology [5], energy conversion and storage [6]. With the increasing demand for energy has attracted broad research on energy storage and conversion devices from alternative energy sources [7–9]. As anode materials applied in lithium ion battery, although LDHs themselves possess a high specific capacity [10], the extremely low electronic conductivity, slow ion diffusion ability and the huge volume changing seriously limit its practice applications [11]. To overcome these shortcomings, converting metal hydroxides into metal oxides by annealing treatment is a feasible solution [12]. On the other hand, the composite with matrix materials can also protect the fragile structure without changing the composition and structure of LDHs [10,11]. To best our knowledge, NiCo-LDH as the most representative double hydroxide, the electrochemical properties are still not completely boosted [13,14]. In this instance, it is highly desired to develop a facile and effective strategy based on surface interactions which ultra-thin NiCo-LDH uniformly arranged on matrix material towards to the 3D conductive network and open architecture. Thereby reducing the huge volume change during Li ion intercalation and enhancing the electrochemical activity. For carbon conversion materials such as graphene, carbon nanotubes and carbon nanowires, inducing the assembly of LDH into an open 3D conductive network often requires complex surface modification to complete tedious assembly [15–18]. Herein, we focused on the new member of the two-dimensional materials family (MXenes), which can be obtained by selectively etching Al in HF or HF-forming etchants for an appropriate time from the precursor Ti3AlC2 [19,20]. During the process of etching Al, general formula changes from M n +1AX n to M n +1X n T x , where T x represent the various surface terminations (OH, O, and/or F groups). With the substitution of T x for A, the strong metallic bonds between M and A eventually turn into two-dimensional materials linked by Van der Waals forces [21,22]. Because of the existence of these surface functional groups, Ti3C2 MXene in water has the negatively charge (ζ-potential of about −40 mV) [23,24], the positively charged nickel-cobalt ions can be anchored on the negatively charged nature of the Ti3C2 MXene surface by electrostatic forces and the ultra-thin, bended, wrinkled and larger interlayer spaced NiCo-LDH are built on the MXene surface (NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2). Unlike free addition NiCo-LDH, designed and synthesized NiCo-LDH in MXene conductive network by using surface-confined strategy can overcome the low ion diffusion capability, poor conductivity, and structure degradation problems. Furthermore, strong interfacial interaction and matched electronic coupling make NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 not only guarantee the excellent rate ability (1076.7 mAh g−1 for 0.1 A g−1, and 370.6 mAh g−1 for 10 A g−1), but also significantly improve cycle life (800 cycles without reduction at 5 A g−1). The excellent performance of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 in lithium ion batteries provides a wider application prospect for double metal hydroxide in the field of energy conversion and storage. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 nanocomposites material The detailed process of Ti3C2 MXene synthesis can be found in the Supporting Information. In general, the as-prepared d-Ti3C2 (185 mg) was added to the conical flask containing 300 mL deionized water and the ultrasound was applied for 30 min. 1 mmol nickel chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O), 1 mmol cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6H2O), were added into the above solution. Subsequently, 8.75 mmol hexamethylenetetramine (HMT) was added with magnetic stirring, the solution was treated at 95 °C for 5 h in argon atmosphere. Afterwards, the solid residue was collected by centrifugation for several times with water and alcohol before freeze-drying and named NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2. For comparison, the high content of d-Ti3C2 (370.0 mg) (named NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2-H, the molar rate of Ti3C2:Co:Ni = 2:1:1), and less amount of d-Ti3C2 (92.5 mg) (named NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2-L, the molar rate of Ti3C2:Co:Ni = 0.75:1:1), d-Ti3C2 (0 mg) (named NiCo-LDH) and graphene oxide (GO) (30.0 mg) (named NiCo-LDH/GO, the molar rate of GO:Co:Ni = 1:1:1) were mixed with 1 mmol NiCl2·6H2O, 1 mmol CoCl2·6H2O, 8.75 mmol HMT under the same condition as described above. 2.2 Material characterization The morphology of the sample was characterized with Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) (Hitachi, S-4800) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (FEI Talos). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a d-MAX 2500 spectrometer. The surface structural information was detected by Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy (EQUINOX55) and Raman spectroscopy (E55+FRA106) using laser excitation at 532 nm. The binding energy was studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (ESCALAB 250Xi). The thickness of the samples was determined by Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) (SPA-300HV/SPI3800N). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) of samples can be measured by ASAP 2020. The weight percent of Ni, Co and Ti element in the sample was measured by Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) (ICAP6300). 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The as-prepared materials (NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2, NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2-H, NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2-L, NiCo-LDH or d-Ti3C2), acetylene black and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) were mixed in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) with a weight ratio of 70:15:15. Average mass loading of the electrodes was ~1.5 mg cm−2. The electrolyte was 1 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) (1:1 v:v%). The battery performance was tested with GCD method on Battery Testing System (BTS, CT-4008, Neware, China) with a voltage window of 0.01 to 3 V. CV measurements were conducted in the voltage range of 3‒0.01 V (versus Li/Li+) on CHI660E. All capacity was calculated based on the weight of the active material. EIS was tested in a frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz on PARSTAT 3000A-DX. 3 Results and discussion The synthesis process and reaction mechanism of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 nanosheets is shown in Fig. 1 . Without the help of Ti3C2 MXene (Fig. 1a), Ni2+ and Co2+ ions can react with hydroxyl groups formed by hydrolysis of HMT to form nickel and cobalt hydroxide monomers. Due to the presence of dissolved oxygen in water and the hydrolysate of HMT, divalent cobalt is partially oxidized to trivalent cobalt. Through olation reactions and crystallization trivalent cobalt, divalent nickel and the remaining unoxidized divalent cobalt hydroxide monomers are converted to NiCo-LDH nanoflower which contains accounts for a large proportion of β-phase crystal (interlayer spacing of ≈4.6 Å) and possession of a small proportion of α-phase crystal (interlayer spacing of ≈8.1 Å) [25,26]. The colloidal Ti3C2 MXene solution can be selectively etched by HCl/LiF from Ti3AlC2 and sonicated to obtain a dark green (Fig. S1a). With the addition of Ni and Co ions (Fig. S1b), the sediment can be observed because of the electrostatic interaction happened between the metal cation and Ti3C2 MXene (Fig. S1c). Therefore, NiCo-LDH nanosheets can be in situ grown on the surface of Ti3C2 MXene under hydrothermal conditions. Furthermore, it can effectively inhibit the generation of β-phase with the unique interaction forces between Ti3C2 and NiCo-LDH, which is derived from the structural degradation of the α-phase [27]. As a result, the ultra-thin, bended, and wrinkled NiCo-LDH anchored on Ti3C2 MXene firmly with an interlayer spacing of ≈8.1 Å can be successfully synthesized, which will be more conducive to the diffusion of electrolyte ions and lithium ions to the reaction sites. FE-SEM observations indicate that the obtained Ti3AlC2 exhibits the typical layered structure (Fig. S2a). The etched Ti3C2 MXene has an accordion-like morphology (Fig. S2b), and the delaminated Ti3C2 MXene possess a planar surface with a transverse size of ~300 nm (Fig. S3). The unique two-dimensional structure and large surface area of Ti3C2 MXene facilitates the nucleation and uniform growth of 3D interconnected NiCo-LDH network on the surface of Ti3C2(Fig. 2 b, c). Without the supporting of Ti3C2 MXene, only the flower-like NiCo-LDH can be obtained under the same conditions (Fig. S2c). We also synthesized different ratios (NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2-H and NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2-L) and NiCo-LDH/GO under the same conditions, the similar morphology for all NiCo-LDH on two-dimensional (2D) material can be obtained, which demonstrates that this surface confinement method is generally applicable to 2D material with negative charges on the surface (Fig. S4a-f). TEM image (Fig. 2d) indicates that the successful growth of the bended and highly wrinkled NiCo-LDH nanosheets on Ti3C2 MXene surface can be successfully assembled. We have noticed that this strategy of surface confinement can effectively reduce the thickness of NiCo-LDH, which is estimated to be <10 nm based on these frizzy nanosheets edges (Fig. 2e), thinner than that of pure NiCo-LDH plate (30–31 nm) based on TEM (Fig. S5a-c) and AFM analysis (Fig. S5e, f). High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) results reveal the distinct lattice fringes of 0.26 nm corresponds to the (012) plane of NiCo-LDH crystal (Fig. 2f). Furthermore, the existence and uniform distribution of Ti, C, Ni, Co and O elements can be detected by elemental mapping analysis of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 nanosheets (Fig. 2g). Fig. S6(a) exhibits a typical XRD pattern of Ti3AlC2, which demonstrates that the obtained sample contains a primary phase of Ti3AlC2 and a small quantity of TiC (< 2 wt%). The structural characteristics of Ti3C2 MXene, NiCo-LDH and NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 powders are determined by XRD (Fig. 3 a). Delamination of Ti3C2 MXene is accompanied by (002), (004) and other series of 00l reflections, resulting in a layered structure of stacked flakes with an interplanar distance of 1.406 nm [28]. Pure NiCo-LDH includes the mainly β phase (interlayer spacing of 4.6 Å) and 22.4 wt% of α phase (interlayer spacing of 8.1 Å) [27,29]. However, when NiCo-LDH nanosheets grow on Ti3C2 MXene surface, the main diffraction peaks at 2θ of 19.2°, 32.9°, and 38.4°, which corresponding to (001), (100), and (101) planes of the β-phase hydroxides, almost disappear, and only α-phase with super-large interlayer spacing can be observed. The same phenomenon also occurs in NiCo-LDH/GO (Fig. S6b). Furthermore, the XRD results indicate that the corresponding (002) layer spacing along the c-axis rises from 1.406 nm to 1.560 nm, resulting in the suppressing the restacking of MXene sheets by the formation of NiCo-LDH nanosheets (Fig. 3b). Due to the vertical growth of LDH forming a tunnel-like network between the MXene layers and increasing the layer spacing, the restacking of MXene can be suppressed and fast the diffusion ability of ions. To further confirm the synthesized α-NiCo-LDH on Ti3C2 nanosheets, the FT-IR spectroscopy was performed (Fig. 3c). Due to the stretching vibrations of -OH group contributed by the brucite-like layers, the lattice water and the interlayer water molecules, the square-built absorption band associated with 3446 cm−1 and 1635 cm−1 can be observed for both NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 and NiCo-LDH samples [30,31]. Two faint absorption band at 2923 and 2855 cm−1 of asymmetric stretching of C—H can be attributed to the insertion of HMT molecules during the formation of hydroxide monomers by hydrothermal reaction [32]. A trace amount of interlayer CO3 2− anions for charge balance at 1399 cm−1 may result from the micro-dissolution of CO2 in the air and/or oxidation of HMT during the reaction [27]. The most important is the disappearance of the band at 3637 cm−1, belong to the free-OH groups of the typical β-phase, which can further prove that α-NiCo-LDH successfully grows on Ti3C2 nanosheets [33]. The Raman spectra of NiCo-OH can be seen in Fig. S6(c), sharp peaks at ~445.4 and ~508.6 cm−1 observed for sample can be assigned to NiCo-LDH [34]. Compared with Ti3C2 MXene, NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 not only have the characteristic peak of Ti3C2 (~135.5, ~274.1, ~406.2 and ~618.8 cm−1) [35–39], but also have peaks belonging to LDH at the wavelength of ~548 cm−1 (Fig. 3d) [13]. And the FT-IR also shows Ti3C2 MXene characteristic peak at 2980 cm−1 (Fig. S7) in NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 (Fig. 3c). The Raman and the FT-IR results confirm the existence of Ti3C2 MXene and the incorporation of Ti3C2 MXene into NiCo-LDH. XPS was applied to further clarify the state bonding between NiCo-LDH and Ti3C2 MXene. The binding energy of C1s for Ti3C2 MXene at 284.80 eV, 286.03 eV and 282.78 eV can be assigned to CC, CO, C-Ti-Tx, respectively (Fig. 3e) [40]. The C-Ti-Tx is completely transformed into C-Ti at 281.53 eV, which demonstrates that the terminated groups (Tx) on Ti3C2 MXene are replaced entirely by NiCo-LDH [40,41]. The peak at 288.78 eV corresponding to OCO can enhance the bonding strength between the LDH and Ti3C2 substrate, which is also reported in the CoNi-LDH/GO system (Fig. S9) [29,42,43]. In addition, the high resolution XPS of Ti 2p spectrum of the NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 nanosheets can be fitted into four main peaks corresponding to the Ti-C, Ti2+, Ti3+, and Ti-O, respectively (Fig. 3f) [35,40,44–46]. The percentage of Ti-O bond increases from 5.50% in the Ti3C2 MXene to 25.09% in the NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2, however, no TiO2 can be found in XRD results (Fig. 3a). It indicates the NiCo-LDH can be successfully grown on the surface of Ti3C2 MXene via oxygen (OCO, Ti-O), and the coverage of LDH can effectively inhibit the further oxidation of Ti3C2 MXene. The results imply that the construction of NiCo-LDH and MXene is strong covalent bond interaction rather than simply physical contact, which can be further evidenced by Ti 2p peaks migrate to lower regions of binding energy contrast with Ti3C2 MXene [47]. The analysis of composition and surface chemical state about NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 can be found in supporting information. 3D interconnected conductive network structure can be formed by self-assembly of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 MXene, which could exhibit excellent lithium ion storage performance. Therefore, CR2032 coin-type cells with NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2, NiCo-LDH/GO, NiCo-LDH and Ti3C2 MXene as the working electrode and lithium metal foils as the counter electrode are fabricated to study the lithium ion storage performance [48]. Fig. 4 (a) shows the 1st, 2nd and 5th cyclic voltammetry (CV) curve of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 electrodes with the voltage window of 0.01−3.0 V at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s− 1 (vs. Li+/Li). One reduction and three oxidation peaks can be detected during the first cycle of lithium intercalation-deintercalation. The apparent cathodic peak located at potentials ~0.71 V is contributed by forming the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film on electroactive materials (containing Li2CO3 and alkyl carbonates via electrolyte decomposition and the trap of the lithium in crystal lattice) [49,50], the process of transition from Co (Ni) ions to Co (Ni) in metallic state (describing by the following equation: M(OH)2 + 2Li+ + 2e− → M + 2LiOH) [10,51] and the reversible decomposition of the intermediate product LiOH (describing by the following equation: 2LiOH+ 2Li+ + 2e−→ Li2O + 2LiH) [11,52,53]. The inconspicuous anodic peak located at 1.96 V should be ascribed to Li+ de-insertion process from MXene [35,54]. For the intense anodic peak located at 1.46 V represent the formation of LiOH and the multistep oxidation of metallic state Co to the corresponding hydroxide [53,55]. For the anodic peak located at 2.32 V represent the multistep oxidation of metallic state Ni to the corresponding hydroxides [52,55]. After the first cycle, the broad cathodic peak disappears and splits into two relatively weak peaks during the subsequent reduction process, which reveals that the irreversible SEI film has been formed on the surface of the active material [56]. In subsequent cycles, compared to NiCo-LDH (Fig. S10), NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 shows the almost superposition CV curves, resulting in the highly reversible electrochemical behavior in the process of lithium ions intercalation and deintercalation [57]. Fig. 4(b) shows the first two laps of GCD voltage profiles at a current density of 0.1 A g−1 with cutoff voltage window of 0.01–3.0 V. The initial discharge/charge capacity dropped from 1879.9 to 1108.9 mAh g−1 and 1827.3 to 1266.4 mAh g−1, with the initial coulombic efficiency of 59.0% and 69.3%, for NiCo-LDH/GO and NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2, respectively. The NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 exhibits the higher initial coulombic efficiency than that of NiCo-LDH/GO. The low initial coulombic efficiency could be caused by the formation of SEI film and the irreversible side reaction between Li+ and electrolyte. Ti3C2 MXene has a relatively low initial capacity of 410 mAh g−1 (Fig. 5 d) than that of NiCo-LDH (1939.5 mAh g−1, Fig S11). Ti3C2 MXene contributes very less for the capacity of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2, however, it can boost the rate performance of layered double hydroxides in lithium-ion battery. Furthermore, the introduction of Ti3C2 greatly reduces the thickness of the NiCo-LDH nanosheets from the TEM and AFM results (Figs. 2e, S5), increases the interlayer spacing and exposes more active sites to facilitate the diffusion ability of lithium ions. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is shown in Fig. 4(c), the inset is an equivalent circuit model. Apparently, the fitting results show the charge-transfer impedance (Fig. 4c) of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 electrodes (R ct = 74.8 Ω) is two times lower than that of NiCo-LDH (R ct = 180.9 Ω). Since Ti3C2 MXene has much better charge-transfer impedance than that of GO (Fig. S12) [58], NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 has lower charge-transfer impedance than that of NiCo-LDH/GO. The rate capability of the obtained samples has been examined at different current densities (Fig. 4d). NiCo-LDH has a large volume change during lithium intercalation and deintercalation, so the large changes of volume could cause the rapidly degradation of the capacity. The results demonstrate that the NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 shows the superior rate capability compare to the NiCo-LDH/GO (Fig. 4d). At low current densities (<1 A g−1), NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 and NiCo-LDH/GO show the similar specific capacity (Table 1 ). When the current density is higher than 1 A g−1, the specific capacity of NiCo-LDH/GO drops faster than that of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2. In the next 50 cycles at varied current densities of 1–10 A g−1 (Table 2 ). NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 shows excellent rate performance with a high reversible capacity of 923.1 mAh g−1 at 1 A g−1. Even at 10 A g−1 (the charge/discharge is completed within only 96.5 s), the NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 still exhibits a capacity as high as 370.6 mAh g−1. When current density returns to 1 A g−1, an average specific capacity of 910 mAh g−1 can be maintained. Due to this unique structural design, ultra-thin NiCo-LDH grown on Ti3C2 substrate greatly reduces the internal stress generated when Li ions are embedded, resulting in the stable structure of NiCo-LDH. Pure NiCo-LDH can only retain 10% of initial capacity after 200 cycles, and Ti3C2 MXene itself does not have high capacity (Fig. 4e). With the incorporation of Ti3C2, the capacity of NiCo-LDH can keep almost constant. Furthermore, the presence covalent bonds of Ti-O and C(O)O makes NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 having stronger interfacial interaction compare to NiCo-LDH/GO which only has a C(O)O bond. It means that NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 can withstand stronger volume expansion than NiCo-LDH/GO, maintains a capacity of 562 mAh g−1 at 5.0 A g−1 for 800 cycles without degradation. On the contrary, the CoNi-LDH/GO shows a rapid capacity loss over 36.6% after 800 cycles. In order to further understand the stabilization of Ti3C2 MXene for NiCo-LDH, we applied SEM to observe the surface morphology of the electrode before and after the cycle. The NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 electrode has a flat surface for fresh and after the first discharge (Fig. 5a, b). Even after 200 cycles, only few holes appear on the surface of the electrode (Fig. 5c). While some holes appear on the surface of the NiCo-LDH electrode after the first discharge (Fig. 5d,e), and the surface topography is completely destroyed after 200 cycles, a large amount of active material is detached from the current collector (Fig. 5f), resulting in the fast decreasing of specific capacity during cycling. Ti3C2 MXene can effectively boost the volume expansion after lithium ion intercalation in NiCo-LDH, reducing the thickness increase from 117.0% (NiCo-LDH) to 19.2% (NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2). This facilitates the formation of a stable SEI film and promotes structural stability (Fig. 5g, h). After 200 cycles, NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 is still firmly attached to the current collector (Fig. 5i) rather than peeled off from the current collector (Fig. 5i). Moreover, NiCo-LDH is still anchored onto the surface of Ti3C2 MXene (Fig. S13a, b, c) after 800 cycles. The content of NiCo-LDH in the nanocomposites can be calculated to be 71.0 wt% (NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2-L), 60.4 wt% (NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2), and 43.3 wt% (NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2-H) by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). For the sample with high content of NiCo-LDH, β-phase NiCo-LDH cannot fully change to α-phase NiCo-LDH. β-phase NiCo-LDH can be detected by XRD in NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2-L (Fig. S14a), which causes a negative effect on electrochemical performance (Figs. S15, S14c, e). While no β-phase exists (Fig. S14b) in NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2-H. A decrease in α-phase NiCo-LDH content also leads to the capacity decay (Fig. S14d, f). Therefore, NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 sample can reach the optimized Li ion storage in this work. Fig. 6 (a) shows the BET surface area of Ti3C2 MXene is poor (7.9 m2/g). However, after introducing Ti3C2 MXene in NiCo-LDH system, a nearly fourfold increasing (80.5 m2/g) than NiCo-LDH (22.8 m2/g) can be achieved. Furthermore, 3D conductive network and open architecture can also increase the pore­volume distribution about two times higher than that of NiCo-LDH with the pore-size from 15 nm to 2000 nm (Fig. 6b), resulting in a fast lithium ion diffusion and low volumetric expansion during the ions insertion-deinsertion process for NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2. The electrochemical kinetics of lithium storage mechanism of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 were studied using CV tests in different scan rates from 0.1 to 5 mV s−1 (Fig. 6c). The relationship between the measured current (i) with scan rate (ν) can be described by the following equation: [59] (1) i = a v b (2) lg ( i ) = b lg ( v ) + lg ( a ) where i denotes the peak current, υ denotes the sweep rate, a is a constant and b means the slope of the lg(υ)-lg(i) plot [60]. If the value of b is approximately 1, a capacitive behavior plays a major role. If the value of b is approximately 0.5, it means that the diffusion controlled process plays a major role [61]. The b value of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 is 0.84 and 0.88 for anodic and cathodic, respectively (Fig. 6d), which gives a strong evidence of typical capacitive behavior process in lithium storage [62]. Through the following equation about current response at a fixed potential, the contribution ratio of capacitive component to the total capacity can be further quantified. It can be expressed as the combination of two mentioned mechanisms: the capacitive effects (k 1 υ) and diffusion controlled processes (k 2 υ 1/ 2) [63] (3) i ( V ) = k 1 v + k 2 v 1 / 2 k 1 is the slope of the i(V)/υ 1/2 υ 1/2 plot. For better analysis, Eq. (3) is rearranged slightly to (4) i ( V ) / v 1 / 2 = k 1 v 1 / 2 + k 2 As shown in Fig. 6(e), the percentage of the capacitive contribution increases from 46.3% to 85.9% gradually with the increasing of scan rate. In addition, Fig. 6(f) gives the typical voltage profile for the capacitive current (grid area) in comparison to the total current. Fig. S16 shows the detailed calculation process. Our layered double hydroxides exhibit capacitive behavior during rapid lithium ion diffusion, which makes NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 nanosheets having high rate performance. To elucidate the underlying mechanism of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 for superior rate performance, we carried out a series of density function theory (DFT) calculations, as summarized in Fig. 6. The computational method and details have been presented in the Supplementary Information. As mentioned in Fig. 3(a), the mainly exposed surface of NiCo-LDH in the experiments is (001) slab, and we noticed that the α-phase NiCo-LDH has a considerably high interlayer spacing of 8.1 Å, implying the interaction between the slabs in z direction is negligible. Hence, a single-layer p(2 × 2) unit cells of NiCo-LDH was constructed with a 20 Å vacuum along the vertical direction to avoid the interactions between the periodic images. Taking Co(OH)2 as an example, to analyze lithium ion intercalation-deintercalation process more deeply, the interaction energy Ei as well as the theoretical capacities were carefully examined, as illustrated in Fig. 7 (a). It can be clearly seen that the values of Ei rapidly decrease from approximately −4 to −18 eV with the increasing of Li concentration, corresponding the theoretical capacities of Li for four typical steps are calculated to be 288, 577, 1154 and 1731 mAh g−1, respectively. The redox of Co ions/Co0 contributed a third of the capacity, and the reversible conversion of LiOH contributed a larger proportion. In fact, some research results show that metal nanoparticles are essential in the complicated electrolytes of sealed LIBs, promote the smooth progress of LiOH reversible reaction [53,64]. Furthermore, the theoretical predictions have completely verified the lithium ion intercalation process on NiCo-LDH-based anode materials, as proposed in Refs. [10,51–53,55]. That is, Co(OH)2 reacts with Li obeying the following reactions, step one: Co(OH)2 + Li+ + e − → CoOH + LiOH; step two: CoOH + LiOH + Li+ + e − → Co + 2LiOH; step three: Co + 2LiOH + 2Li+ + 2e− → Co + LiOH + LiH + Li2O; step four: Co + LiOH + LiH + Li2O + 2Li+ + 2e− → Co + 2LiH + 2Li2O, as displayed in Fig. 7(b). Since the electrical conductivity is strongly correlated with the electrochemical performance of an electrode material, the density of states (DOS) as well as the projected density of states (PDOS) for each step were further calculated (Fig. 7c). It can be observed that all the models considered here either before or after adsorption of Li atoms exhibit metallic-like character because considerable electronic states have been found near their Fermi levels. In addition, the -F and -OH terminated groups on Ti3C2 MXene surfaces were removed during the reaction process (Fig. S8a), resulting in the high electrical conductivity, lower diffusion barrier, low open circuit voltage and high theoretical Li capacity [65]. Our results also reveal that Ti3C2 phase provides good electrical conductivity and high structural stability in NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2, beneficial for prompting the rate performance of NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 anode material. Combining theoretical calculations and experimental results, NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 system can be used as a highly desirable and promising anode material for lithium ion batteries. The comparison of other MXene composites for Li ions storage under high current density is shown in Table 3 . The excellent performance under high current density indicates NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 has a wide range of application prospects for Li ions anode materials. 4 Conclusions In this work, through the electrostatic interaction between the metal cation and Ti3C2 MXene, the ultra-thin, bended, wrinkled and larger interlayer spaced NiCo-LDH nanosheets on the Ti3C2 MXene surface can be successfully synthesized. NiCo-LDH tightly anchored onto the Ti3C2 MXene surface, greatly strengthening the structural durability. The unique microstructure of NiCo-LDH exposes more active sites to facilitate the diffusion of lithium ions inside the active material. The layered NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 MXene can greatly reduce the volume expansion of NiCo-LDH during Li ion intercalation. As a result, the outstanding performance of NiCo-LDH for lithium storage is completely boosting, which exhibits excellent rate capacities of 1076.7‒370.6 mAh g−1 for the varied current densities of 0.1‒10 A g−1 and superior long cycle capability of 562 mAh g−1 at 5.0 A g−1 for 800 cycles without degradation. Finally, a series of density function theory calculations confirmed that NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 system can be used as a highly desirable and promising anode material for lithium ion batteries. coredata.dc:description: Nickel/cobalt-layered double hydroxides (NiCo-LDH) have been attracted increasing interest in the applications of anode materials for lithium ion battery (LIB), but the low cycle stability and rate performance are still limited its practice applications. To achieve high performance LIB, the surface-confined strategy has been applied to design and fabricate a new anode material of NiCo-LDH nanosheet anchored on the surface of Ti3C2 MXene (NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2). The ultra-thin, bended and wrinkled α-phase crystal with an interlayer spacing of 8.1 Å can arrange on the conductive substrates Ti3C2 MXene directly, resulting in high electrolyte diffusion ability and low internal resistance. Furthermore, chemical bond interactions between the highly conductive Ti3C2 MXene and NiCo-LDH nanosheets can greatly increase the ion and electron transport and reduce the volume expansion of NiCo-LDH during Li ion intercalation. As expected, the discharge capacity of 562 mAh g−1 at 5.0 A g−1 for 800 cycles without degradation can be achieved, rate capability and cycle performance are better than that of NiCo-LDH (~100 mAh g−1). Furthermore, the density function theory (DFT) calculations were performed to demonstrate that NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 system can be used as a highly desirable and promising anode material for lithium ion battery.

coredata.dc:title: NiCo-LDH/Ti3C2 MXene hybrid materials for lithium ion battery with high-rate capability and long cycle life
